properties.description: The Boston Tea Party occurred on December 16, 1773, when Samuel Adams and the Sons of Liberty led American colonists in boarding British ships and dumping 342 chests of tea into Boston Harbor.
The Tea Act of 1773, which granted the British East India Company a monopoly on tea sales in the American colonies.

The mechanism through which the Tea Act led to rebellion operated as follows: (1) The Tea Act imposed taxation without colonial representation in Parliament, violating fundamental principles of self-governance; (2) This created both economic pressure on local merchants who were undercut by the monopoly and ideological mobilization around constitutional principles; (3) Groups like the Sons of Liberty channeled this discontent into organized resistance; (4) The resistance culminated in direct action against British property.
The imperial control mechanism, where legislative components like the Tea Act created economic and political pressures necessary to test colonial loyalty and extract revenue.
The revolution was primarily driven by constitutional principles, specifically opposition to taxation without representation.

The revolution was primarily driven by colonial merchants' economic interests rather than constitutional principles, with wealthy merchants manipulating popular sentiment to protect smuggling operations and avoid British taxes.
